Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               with extensive reference to the collections of the Natural History Museum (BMNH),
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               the BMNH collection. This species was not recorded from Tanzania by Carcasson
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               measurement of small samples from the BMNH collections, using STANDARD
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               BMNH collected in March 1912 by Alluaud and Jeannel, at 1000 m on the Himo
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               it is included here as an element of the lower slope fauna (700–1800 m). The BMNH
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               has a male from Meru, and two males from Old Moshi. In addition, the BMNH has a
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               (1910: 12) also records dardanus from the “Nordseite”. The BMNH specimen could be
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               However, two old males in the BMNH, one labelled “Old Moshi”, the other “6 miles
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               represented by a pair in BMNH collected by Arthur Rydon, is very close to Mount
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               pect that “Ngorongoro” probably represents a misinterpretation of a BMNH specimen
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               (1975: 20) gives a record for Moshi (c.800–900 m). Specimens in the BMNH col-
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               1800 m) fauna based on a pair in the BMNH from New Moshi, “800 m”, collected by
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               BMNH labelled Moshi. However, if this taxon is still present on the lower slopes, given
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               ophidicephalus from mixed forest along the Sanya river, a specimen in the BMNH
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               in BMNH suggest that the Kilimanjaro Swallowtail might have occurred down to and
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222933.2011.596635.pdf.txt:                                                               lower slopes (e.g. a specimen in BMNH from New Moshi).

Journal-of-Natural-History/00222930701515488.pdf.txt:                                                               alcohol (BMNH, LZUY, MAKB, MHNG, MMB, NHMB, USNM).
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222930701515488.pdf.txt:                                                               Indo-Australian Region (collections of BMNH, MHNG, NHMB, and others). Its internal
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222930701515488.pdf.txt:                                                               Kenya (BMNH data) might form a monophyletic group. P. fuscivenosum is probably closely
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222930701515488.pdf.txt:                                                               and other African countries (BMNH, MHNG, NHMB data). From the eight Cameroon
Journal-of-Natural-History/00222930701515488.pdf.txt:                                                               klaineana in nurseries and young plantations in West Africa (Brunck 1965; BMNH data).

JVP/pdfs/2012/02724634.2012.686467.pdf.txt:                                                                           ABSTRACT—The plesiosaur specimen NHMUK OR49202, from the Lias Group of Lyme Regis, consists of a complete
JVP/pdfs/2012/02724634.2012.686467.pdf.txt:                                                                           to Plesiosaurus and comparison with the type specimen of ‘Plesiosaurus’ macrocephalus (NHMUK OR1336) suggests that
JVP/pdfs/2012/02724634.2012.686467.pdf.txt:                                                                           it is taxonomically distinct. Therefore, NHMUK OR49202 is made the holotype of a new genus and species: Anningasaura
JVP/pdfs/2012/02724634.2012.686467.pdf.txt:                                                                                                                                             the Lias Group of Lyme Regis, Dorset, England (NHMUK
JVP/pdfs/2012/02724634.2012.686467.pdf.txt:                                                                                                                                             Furthermore, we observe several differences between NHMUK
JVP/pdfs/2012/02724634.2012.686467.pdf.txt:                                                                                                                                             several plesiomorphies suggesting that NHMUK OR49202 rep-
